customer_addr:
107 Chieftan Way
LAB ANML RSCS 101 BIOMED RSCH FAC
TALLAHASSEE, FL 32306

citations.narrative:
On April 21, 2023, a vole was found with an injury to its right front leg. According to the facility’s adverse event report,
while the vole did not appear overtly painful on veterinary examination, the vole and its cage mates were euthanized
because they were no longer eligible for the study. On April 25, 2023, a vole in a different room was found with the right
front limb caught in the wire bar lid close to where the water bottle attaches to the cage. The injured animal and its cage
mate were similarly euthanized. The cause of the injuries was found to be due to improper cage manufacturing such that
there was a previously unobserved small gap between where the water bottle attaches to the cage and the cage wire,
allowing animals’ legs to get caught. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate
for the animals involved. The indoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Corrected by replacing cages with a new style of lid prior to inspection on July 31, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian and other facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
David Mersereau, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
On April 21, 2023, a vole was found with an injury to its right front leg. According to the facility’s adverse event report, 
while the vole did not appear overtly painful on veterinary examination, the vole and its cage mates were euthanized 
because they were no longer eligible for the study. On April 25, 2023, a vole in a different room was found with the right 
front limb caught in the wire bar lid close to where the water bottle attaches to the cage. The injured animal and its cage 
mate were similarly euthanized. The cause of the injuries was found to be due to improper cage manufacturing such that 
there was a previously unobserved small gap between where the water bottle attaches to the cage and the cage wire, 
allowing animals’ legs to get caught. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate 
for the animals involved. The indoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
Corrected by replacing cages with a new style of lid prior to inspection on July 31, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian and other facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
David Mersereau, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
